comments.commentBody: The views you attribute to Bernie are pure fiction.  His vision of capitalism is mainstream in many of the advanced nations and was the norm here before Saint Ronald came along and began tampering with the social contract.

To Ken ~
Re: "Weren't you pleased when we no longer faced the prospect of another Bush in the White House?" I would prefer Jeb Bush over Trump.
Re: "...because she is a bigger hawk than Obama...." Well it looks like Trump will surround himself with even bigger hawks and he is more ignorant than Obama & Clinton. I did not like the drone strikes either but am not convinced Hillary would have continued them.
Re: "Who are Clinton's friends?......" I disagree that she was/is only comfortable among the wealthy. I know people who have met her and to a person they describe her as a warm person who LISTENS. Like you, I don't like that a long time ago she sat on the Wal Mart board. Maybe one of the reasons was she was from Arkansas; at one time Sam Walton's stores were filled with products made in the USA. I dislike what Wal Mart is today, personally do not shop there. But, I despise what Trump represents and the people like Carl Icahn he associates with.
Re: "Finally, I suspect that Hillary could not have passed let alone funded her infrastructure improvement plan for the same reason that Obama couldn't." Strongly disagree on this one. Hillary made friends on both sides of the aisle as a Senator. She was on record as saying that one of the first things she would do was sit down with members of Congress and drink with them. She was well liked in the Senate and knows how to work the system better than Obama.
The better woman and candidate lost and I am sad about it.

"So, if MR. Sanders first act should be to toss out the leadership of the Democratic Party and start anew."

Mr Sanders has already pushed the candidacy of Congressional Progressive Caucus (which Bernie co-founded) leader Keith Ellison as the DNC chairman. That suggests that this is indeed his first move. If the Democratic Party doesn't want to follow him, then I for one would be happy to follow Bernie straight out of the Democratic Party into parts unknown.

The U.S. is disgraced by its contrast of extreme poverty and grotesque wealth.
Elizabeth Warren is second only to Bernie in fighting for greater economic equality.
The glass ceiling would be in trillion fragments today if the Dems hadn't chosen Wall Street Hillary.
Really? You travel around the world much? The extremes in wealth are much greater in 99% of other countries. They aren't Disneyland.

It seems as if America was more connected during the periods when nationalism and protectionism was more emphasized.  A town like Newton, Iowa, (population 15,000 today) had a good number of washing machine manufacturers in the early 1900s.  At its peak, Maytag employed 3000 there.  But, in 2007 the plant closed.  Globalization took away some of the contribution that rural towns were making to the fabric of society, and at the same time reducing the choices and income available there. So, would you not expect "widening political divergence" and alienation?

I think the main reason that Hillary was defeated was due to the fact that she was a Clinton, not that she was a woman. I'm sure that being a woman was an issue for part of the electorate, but she had built up a multi-decade record that people did not trust. They did not trust that she had the best interests of the country in mind, they did not trust that she would represent them, they did not trust that she understood and sympathized with the common person. In a way this is a backhanded complement, she was judged on her record and found wanting. It therefore cost her the election.

There will be a woman in the White House when she is the strongest candidate, when she shows through actions, not just words, that she represents all Americans, that she believes in service, and has a clear vision where she wants to take the nation. I think after 4 years, perhaps less, of Trump, there will be an opportunity for someone with civility, a vision and an attitude of Servant Leadership to win the White House. It could be a woman if she started preparing now, but expecting it because she is a women, is a losing ticket as Hillary has shown. It will have to be because she is the best person for the job.

The exact same states and voting groups who did not come through for Hillary had already twice elected a black man named Hussein during a war against another Hussein, a black man with Muslim ties amid terror fears about Muslims.

Those particular states and voting blocks had already proved themselves. Calling them bigots now is an excuse to hide from these real reasons, from Hillary herself and those around her as the problem.
Muslim ties? Still peddling falsehoods, are we?

"... you [Sanders] could have benefited from her experience."

That's an interesting statement, because it suggests something that was a major point of the Clinton campaign but wasn't true, namely that Clinton was more experienced than Sanders. She wasn't, not even close, but she sure got people believing it.

Sanders was a mayor for 10 years, then in the House for 16 years, then the Senate for 10, all before running for president for a total of 36 years in elected office. He had won 14 elections, and lost 5 (all but 1 very early on in his political career). He was, in short, the very definition of an experienced and seasoned politician.

Clinton's resume is quite a bit shorter: She was a senator for 8 years, and Secretary of State for 4. She's won 2 elections, and now lost 2. She likes to confuse the issue by claiming her 8 years as First Lady as part of her political experience, but she wasn't really in the hot seat, Bill was.

For years now I have wondered if the inmates were not actually running the asylum. After the election last week I have proof of that. If Bernie can hold the elected government's feet to the fire (whether Democratic or Republican) then we can regain some sanity to our system of democracy.

RE: "So Americans voted for the lesser evil,..."

NO Mark! Americans voted for the much bigger, greater evil, the devil they did not know. Trump doesn't really want to be President, and do all the hard work involved. He wanted to be the winner. He is already trying to figure out how many nights he can sleep in his own bed in Trump Tower. Wonder how long before Pence takes over as POTUS.

How should we reconcile these election results and the anxiety felt by the people in these rural areas with the notion that economic gains were pretty significant in rural areas?  If rural communities are growing at equal rates why are they feeling more angst from globalization?

The taproot is that the United States has always been more sexist than racist. It's just that racism negatively affects males, so the patriarchy obsesses over that, while sexism is all about negatively affecting the mostly invisible girls and women. And this nation finds harming females perfectly acceptable, even a cornerstone of the male status quo natural order. Just look at the nearly 100 nations that now have or have had a female leader but not the U.S. Sexism and institutional violent misogyny is as much a facet of this country as is the Pilgrims, 1776, the Civil War, the Statue of Liberty, the 19th amendment 140 years late, Roe v. Wade a century late, July 4th fireworks, the moon walk, and now the nation's best, smartest and grittiest female politician ever - forced to stand near defenseless against endless physical threats and a tirade of insults hurled by the GOP and Republican voters for 30 years. One of the saddest conversations I've been forced to have with my teen daughter was explaining Trump and the tsunami of vulgar, vile threats against Hillary Clinton while also trying to give my girl some sense of hope that the cesspool inhabited by some American men and women will someday soon clean itself up, especially for the safety and mental well-being of females. It hurts when your daughter asks, "Are we safe?", knowing she refers to rabid, violent and misogynist neighbors, relatives and fellow Americans. Worse, I can't tell her "Yes, we are."
I like the subtlety of the meta-DP.  It fits.

@Mark Pepp
Chicago
"whilst simultaneously doing multinational corporations' bidding by pushing trade agreements"

Do you really believe the Republican party is going to get behind a protectionist agenda. If you do you you're beyond gullible. This will be the first promise to be reneged upon. Who do you think launched the TPP and are it's strongest supporters in congress (clue...it's not the Democrats). You'll probably also be stunned to learn Trump won't tear up NAFTA because Canada and Mexico are our two major trade partners and there are supply chains on which US industry is heavily dependent. You don't seem to have much clue about the REAL respective positions of the two parties. Incidentally the TPP is as much an effort to build an alliance of Asian countries to contain China as it is a trade treaty.

While my heart is with you, I'm in dismay: How was Donald Trump elected? Can we trust this election's results?  Efforts to suppress votes have accelerated since 2000 and the only reason I think they didn't work in Obama's case was because of "early voting" and massive turnout. Fast-forward to Republicans' aggressive gerrymandering, oppressive voter ID laws targeting the poor, elderly, black, and Hispanic citizens; outright voter intimidation; reduced voter poll hours/broken machines/not enough machines; and insecure/hack-able electronic voting software. Trump said the "election would be rigged" repeatedly. What if it he said this to deflect suspicion from anyone questioning the polls and the predictive data that conclusively predicted Clinton would win? Something's just not right here. Not dismissing Trump's supporters and their concerns -- I think the American people have been "played in this election".

Let's not forget about the role that Comey’s FBI played in this election, either. How much did the announcement about Hillary’s newly discovered, "large volumes" of  emails (which proved to be duplications of existing emails or immaterial to the investigation) sway the electorate? In the end, less than 110K votes out of tens of millions cast on Election Day made the difference in the race.

Ann, you are right. Trump ran a typical con man's (liar's) game wherein they accuse first their "mark" or opponent of scheming to do what they themselves are doing thus raising and directing suspicion away from themselves.

By bringing up the method of the con first, liars believe that they will be granted a pass because they have "spotted" the lie first. A clear example occurred during the debates: recall Donald Trump sniffed his was through the debates- a physical reaction to having snorted adderall - for instance - to stay focused. This sniffing had happened on other occasions when Trump had to stay focused - when he started using a TelePrompTer. After the debates, social media was heavily speculating that he was using drugs - the trump team picked this up and responded quickly be suggesting Clinton of used drugs during the debate: the inference was made by trump suggesting Clinton be drug tested before the next debate. Even the media was fooled by this sleight of hand, quickly shifting to the absurdity of the accusation, taking their eyes off the fact that trump was starting to sniff his way through any appearances that required real focus.

Trump pulled this scam throughout the campaign, accusing others of what he himself was doing. The psychology behind this is sociopathy and/or narcissism - the liar/trickster covers their nefarious deed by lying and blaming others to manipulate the attention of the credulous away from their own deeds.

Yes, they were played badly by the media and by the DNC. The vote went as all rational progressive new it would and predicted. Clinton barely squeaked by with a majority barely edging out Trump because she was a lousy, unpopular candidate loaded with baggage -- real and imagined. What is shocking was not the popular vote but the Electoral one.  People do want change. 72%  of Americans who voted last night believed that “the economy is rigged to the advantage of the rich and powerful.” Sixty-eight percent agreed that “traditional parties and politicians don’t care about people like me.” Clinton's policies and history pushing neoliberal economics, bad trade deals and war did not inspire hope. Most of us voted against Trump rather that for Clinton. Most of us a struggling day to day. Most of us do not want war with Russia or more of the same.  I fear Trump. I hope we can learn from Sanders and unite around a stronger progressive vision

HRC campaigned on her record and her jam up social policies, as well as her proven experience, diplomacy and political acumen. It is the lazy press that let the GOP and even Bernie Sanders get away with slinging manure all over her for simply being a smart, qualified and ambitious female. How do I know this, the status quo clutched their man part privates and ran as fast as they could into the arms of a mentally disturbed boorish, ignorant misogynist. That so many women followed suit ought not surprise. While men are physically dangerous, women are often just as misogynist to other women. And when those haters take up the talking snake cudgel of religion, there are few women who make it out alive from that fiery pit.
@citoyen: "Simple to organize" but it took a con-man to do it.
...  and you could always count on Dead Tree Solver.

This is a good one. I really appreciate the history and the photographs.

I want you to know that I am married to an extremely smart woman who early on in the campaign said that if Hillary Clinton were a woman she would have been a shoo-in to the Presidency. I tried to introduce other factors that might have influenced the outcome (nothing original with me only what I read in the Times) but she held fast to the gender as the handicap.

We watch the news together, because she has the only TV, so when Mrs. C gave her concession speech and closed with the little girl roff, tears began to flow from my wife's eyes. It was a profound moment. No one spoke but it was hard to take. I noticed that her statement also brought tears to Bill's eyes.

We came out of the same school system and we now in discussion review our grade classes and as I think back in time the smartest person in class was always a female. The only time I felt that we began to spred apart in academics was in my math and physics classes in the last two years of HS.

I really think we lost out by ending Hillary's career. Women like that don't come along often, and I knew Senator Smith.

One day, I want you to try to explain what happened in Florida, North Carolina, and MIchigan. This did not compute.

In our loyalty to the meme of peaceful transitions of power, we have not listened to those like Mark Crispin Miller who are calling for attention to the evidence that the slight discrepancies between exit polls and computer managed results in such states might be evidence of carefully planned hacking.

@Mark: How much did your shirt cost?  How much would it have cost if it were made in the U.S.?  How much would it have cost if a tariff were imposed that compelled you to purchase one made in the U.S.?

Moi aussi.

You 'n' me are going to have to have a confabulation about that there 'foofaraw'. As English is not my mother tongue, and all.

Clinton's parent were working class/middle class, her mother an abandoned orphan bounced around and denied a higher education. Being smart came naturally to Hillary Rodham it seems, but she earned her admission to Wellesley and then Yale Law. It is more than clear that she treasured those two opportunities and has worked her entire adult life to help more girls around the world have a shot at learning and a fulfilling future.

Actually, we are in a situation that the EC was created for. A demagogue who has hoodwinked a large number of voters can be stopped in the EC. The electors are not bound by law to vote for a candidate, they have agreed to do so, but they can vote for a different candidate as a matter of conscience, or for the good of the country. Just imagine.
Yes, it will be a long haul. But Trump is only a symptom. The disease has been here for decades, and the way to cure it still eludes us as we try sound-bite non-solutions.

Exactly.

But Krugman et al fought the progressive candidate in this race tooth and nail with dishonest arguments, Bernie exposed you as a faux progressive: all of a sudden the programs you claimed are "the Left"'s goals were "unicorns" and utterly impossible/unrealistic/stupid/naive. Sorry, all this stuff works elsewhere and is very much possible, if the pundits don't block the people from demanding them.

Bernie would have wiped the floor with Trump but for the Dem establishment Bernie was as bad as Trump because their goal is to elevate the Dem elite and he would elevate millions of Americans instead.

@Mark: Hillary did, in fact, promise to spend lots of money on job retraining for those workers whose jobs have been lost to global trade.  Should she have nixed those proposals in favor of reopening the coal mines, slashing corporate taxes in hopes that CEOs would bring other vanishing professions back from abroad and imposing tariffs on foreign businesses (whose governments would, needless to say, return the favor with respect to imports from the U.S.)?  American workers are also consumers and closing down the markets isn't the answer to what ails the Rust Belt.

You are right. Ms. Benzizoune, you need to tell your story.  I don't know about your roommate, but many people have weird ideas about the "other" because they don't know any "others."  Thank you for sharing your story, and please know that even NY Times readers need to hear not just from political analysts but from real human beings and the story of their lives.
Many liberals have the same problem.  They don't know anyone who makes a living working with their hands.  They don't know anyone who doesn't think like them.
